reviews: the clutch claw ruins the game because it interrupts hunts by forcing you to stop all your attacks and use this clunky mess to latch onto the monster and soften the the introduction of the clutch claw, the fights were great because you were 100 % focused on killing the monster and dodging the attacks and nothing was interrupting you from doing this other than other monsters the clutch claw wouldn ' t even be so bad if it wasn ' t for the fact that some weapons have to use it twice in order to soften parts the clutch claw does bring some good things to the table such as the flinch shot which is basically free damage but this also kinda sucks cause you can only do it when the monster is not enraged as well as the fact that the monster will most of the time would just knock you off anyways while you ' re trying to do you could play the game without softening parts, you will lose a lot of time in hunts and some investigations have low time limits which means that if you don ' t use the clutch claw, you will basically be wasting your time its not so bad in multiplayer however, as you aren ' t forced to do all of the softening yourself

few minutes if you want to keep doing as much damage as possible which is a bit of a issue i have is with the grind. although the new augmenting system and the way you get the materials for it is an improvement over the old one in my eyes, it ' s still quite grindy. a downside of moving away from investigations is that you ' ll spend most of your endgame grind on the same monsters like kulve are also returning to suck the life out of you. i haven ' t fought the new kulve herself yet but safi ' jiiva becomes old pretty quickly. it ' s much better than high rank kulve though! as for other things that might be worth mentioning : - the new town and hub are great - room customization is pretty neat - many more layered armor sets and also layered weapons allow for more customisation while still letting you deal efficient damage - the story is kinda cheesy and takes itself too seriously just like the base game but not terrible - performance was supposedly quite bad back when the dlc launched. i also got it at launch but apparently i was lucky to have had no technical issues besides a couple of stutters in specific locations ( even though my pc isn ' t exactly a

few minutes if you want to keep doing as much damage as possible which is a bit of a issue i have is with the grind. although the new augmenting system and the way you get the materials for it is an improvement over the old one in my eyes, it ' s still quite grindy. a downside of moving away from investigations is that you ' ll spend most of your endgame grind on the same monsters like kulve are also returning to suck the life out of you. i haven ' t fought the new kulve herself yet but safi ' jiiva becomes old pretty quickly. it ' s much better than high rank kulve though! as for other things that might be worth mentioning : - the new town and hub are great - room customization is pretty neat - many more layered armor sets and also layered weapons allow for more customisation while still letting you deal efficient damage - the story is kinda cheesy and takes itself too seriously just like the base game but not terrible - performance was supposedly quite bad back when the dlc launched. i also got it at launch but apparently i was lucky to have had no technical issues besides a couple of stutters in specific locations ( even though my pc isn ' t exactly a

the hunter adapting and morphing to the new challenge. master rank monsters are just the same as g rank, because of this the clutch claw does fault and slip up a bit. it feels like a forced mechanic to a game that wasn ' t adjusted for it, and even i see that. but even then you just need to find the feel for every monster and choose the times you attack with the claw. this is finding that new breathing room were before was maybe used to sharpen or heal. nor do you even have to use the claw you can legit just let it rot and can play the game just fine. all that being said, if you enjoyed mhw you will most likely enjoy ib and i highly recommend you get it. yes there is some sticky and odd things that are in it, but that isn ' t enough to bog the game down to be bad. everything is pretty much an improvement, all the new and returning monsters are fun and interesting, the story is poo but always has been in every game. i recommend this 11 / 10 more monster hunter is always good.

##ling attack or flinch shot. oh and mr monsters will usually wreck you if you try to clutch claw them, because, again, they spam attacks for most of the fight, so you have to wait till they are exhausted or reeling to wound parts, and you do that instead of straight up doing more damage. wounding is great in multiplayer, as many attacks will benefit from the extra damage, but in single player this is not the case as the wounded part will return to normal in just a couple of minutes and monsters tend to get enraged after several claw attacks making hitting said part more hunts are less fun now against many monsters, compared to the base game, because of their spammy aoe attacks, larger health pools ( even relative to weapon damage at the time of the first encounter ) and the need of wounding to maximize damage ( this is a chore that only gets worse if you use light weapons ). on a more personal thought, i don ' t like how your character never improves, just gets better gear. they still flinch at any monster sneeze even though they have slayed hundreds of them ( why not give us a few points in earplugs for free? ) and they still fall on their butt after being touched by a monster

your op stuff from the base game, you need to adapt, use new mechanics, craft new stuff. as soon as you get to the end - game - hunts take as much as 10 - 15 minutes if you ain ' t a speedrunner. some harder monsters can eat more of your time, but that ' s the point, they are hard. but yeah, i can ' t be bothered tenderizing every minute or so too, so i don ' t. and it ' s fine. speaking of the base game, hunts during the story usually took me the same time as in iceborne. it ' s not that bad. also, on october 1st we are getting a new update with some tweaks to clutch claw, so it ' s better now. will be. you know what i the new stuff huh, that was quite a rant. what else do we have? we have a brand new zone and it ' s really beautiful and fun to explore. one thing tho - hot drinks. gets kinda annoying, but it ' s not a problem. story is actually pretty cool, i do like it. some lore stuff is always good too. still simple, still smacking and slapping monsters so they don ' t do shit, but now

the clutch claw ruins the game because it interrupts hunts by forcing you to stop all your attacks and use this clunky mess to latch onto the monster and soften the the introduction of the clutch claw, the fights were great because you were 100 % focused on killing the monster and dodging the attacks and nothing was interrupting you from doing this other than other monsters the clutch claw wouldn ' t even be so bad if it wasn ' t for the fact that some weapons have to use it twice in order to soften parts the clutch claw does bring some good things to the table such as the flinch shot which is basically free damage but this also kinda sucks cause you can only do it when the monster is not enraged as well as the fact that the monster will most of the time would just knock you off anyways while you ' re trying to do you could play the game without softening parts, you will lose a lot of time in hunts and some investigations have low time limits which means that if you don ' t use the clutch claw, you will basically be wasting your time its not so bad in multiplayer however, as you aren ' t forced to do all of the softening yourself

s engame loop sees you hunting monsters in the guiding lands. a landmass with all the biomes in one map. for each monster you hunt in a zone you level them up. this gives you access to harder monsters and eventually tempered elder dragons. just hunting in the guiding lands is really fun and [ * ] [ b ] final boss : [ / b ] [ spoiler ] fatalis [ / spoiler ] in iceborne is one of the single best end bosses i have fought yet. it was an extremely hard fight, which me and a friend brought down in multiple sittings. each try saw us getting closer to victory bit by bit. as the monster fell to the ground i just couldn ' t not smile. this single boss fight will be an experience i think will not be surpassed so cons [ / h3 ] [ list ] [ * ] [ b ] clutch claw : [ / b ] the dlc ' s main gimmick is the clutch claw, which you use to grapple onto the monster. this added some fun moves to a lot of weapons like lances clutch claw counter and gunlances wyrmstake blast stake ( a stake, which is stuck on a monster and deals extra damage when you hit it

i loved monster hunter world, but with the addition of the clutch claw and making parts weaker to attacks makes this game more annoying than anything. i have over 1000 hours on this and i feel like the clutch claw should not be a main mechanic of the game and making monster with a shit ton of health and moves that literally one shot you very annoying. you can ' t do damage without using the clutch claw and if you use it at the wrong time youre pretty much fucked. just make the clutch claw added damage and not a main mechanic don ' t make it to where you have to weaken a monsters part to do damage. also is it so hard to ask for higher than guard 5? like come on i ' m already getting one shot give me more guard and less chip damage please! till then the game is dead.

having clocked in over 400 hours into the base game, there are glaring issues with some things in this expansion to mhw. some of the things i ' ve noticed with this expansion are less than savory for the game as a whole and call into question some design choices made. firstly, the clutch claw feels way too mandatory for normal play in master rank. since wounding monsters with the claw is now required to deal efficient damage to some breakable or severable parts, you will have to repeat this process likely several times for one monster, especially for specific part breaks like tail cuts. also, light weapons have to do it to one part twice in a row to have the same effect as a heavy weapon, which is stupid and unfair to people who play with such weapons. second, items like flash pods were nerfed way too hard. many monsters seem to now ignore flashes unless they are exactly in front of their face and even when flashed they seem to still have mostly normal fighting capability. third, a lot of monsters are such bullet sponges now that it calls into question if master rank is just a more forced version of the tempered and arch - tempered system. look, i don ' t mind the monsters being a little tankier and a

performance issues have been patched as of this review!! i ' m getting 30 degree lower temps on my cpu! tl ; dr you like base game a lot? buy this. a lot more of the content that you liked in the base game. the reviews are mixed because of performance issues which have since been patched as of jan. hunter world : iceborne is a phenomenal expansion that really extends the experience that the base game offered for hundreds of more hours. there are a lot of reasons why i love this expansion : 1. new monsters as of this review, iceborne adds 31 ( and counting! ) new monsters, a good deal of which are returning flagships from the older games but there are also some new unique ones as well. it is really nice to be able to fight my favorite monsters in world as i always find it tougher these days to return back to the 3ds or switch after being accustomed to the more comfortable experience i had playing world. 2. higher difficulty i ' m not sure if this is a fault of my experience playing the older games but i always found the base game of monster hunter world to be extraordinarily easy. i feel like the only monsters that offer a challenge in the base game are arch

this is not for the faint of heart, iceborne is difficult and is not recommended to anyone who is not familiar with difficult games. there are a few graphical flickers on nvidia cards, you could go back to a older driver set, but it seems like too much of a hassle. also if your playing for the story, there are many other games capcom has made with a better story ( re franchise because mh story in general is the new monsters in mhw : ib are really good and are a lot more fun than some of the monsters in base world, the new world variants they added are not too bad. the game is a lot of fun for those who are generally looking for a challenge but there is some grind ( its not that bad if you ' ve played the base mantles were something they added if your looking to get them investigation are now actually something you want to do, as in the base version of the game you would only really do them if you want to do tempered monsters. in iceborne i ' d say its necessary and vital to get certain armor sets as otherwise its much more time mhw : ib is good just ignore what other people have said about it ( complaining about difficulty. modders, and that

i honestly love monster hunter : world : off, i have a pretty good pc ( ryzen 7, 2060, so i do not have the performance issues and i cannot say how it feels great hunting new monsters, monsters fight more among themselves other than turf weapons, new claw is the best thing in the new it ' s sometimes really annoying to have multiple monsters fight for a long time, and shooting dung at them only makes them wait at the next retreat point for the monster you are still recommend this game though it can be frustrating at times

a great expansion for the base game. while i think that the dlc offers more challenging fights it also holds new ways to fight with the clutch claw ( which will be available to you even in the base game if you buy the dlc ). if you liked monster hunter world i would definitely emplore you to get the dlc

i honestly love monster hunter : world : off, i have a pretty good pc ( ryzen 7, 2060, so i do not have the performance issues and i cannot say how it feels great hunting new monsters, monsters fight more among themselves other than turf weapons, new claw is the best thing in the new it ' s sometimes really annoying to have multiple monsters fight for a long time, and shooting dung at them only makes them wait at the next retreat point for the monster you are still recommend this game though it can be frustrating at times

one of the best expensions i ` ve ever played. 35 new monsters, new maps, new moves, new systems, new hub, new endgame, tons of new gear etc. clutch claw is probably the only real controversial addition. it is fun, but also forced on you and monsters are designed with you using it in mind. liked world, loved iceborne.

this is an excellent expansion with a lot of content. i highly recommend it if you liked the original game, as this expansion adds to it in every way. lots of new monsters, new weapon moves, new weapons and armor, new areas, new master rank, and more. i have not experienced any technical problems so far.

this is not for the faint of heart, iceborne is difficult and is not recommended to anyone who is not familiar with difficult games. there are a few graphical flickers on nvidia cards, you could go back to a older driver set, but it seems like too much of a hassle. also if your playing for the story, there are many other games capcom has made with a better story ( re franchise because mh story in general is the new monsters in mhw : ib are really good and are a lot more fun than some of the monsters in base world, the new world variants they added are not too bad. the game is a lot of fun for those who are generally looking for a challenge but there is some grind ( its not that bad if you ' ve played the base mantles were something they added if your looking to get them investigation are now actually something you want to do, as in the base version of the game you would only really do them if you want to do tempered monsters. in iceborne i ' d say its necessary and vital to get certain armor sets as otherwise its much more time mhw : ib is good just ignore what other people have said about it ( complaining about difficulty. modders, and that

a strong improvement over the base game, mhw : iceborne adds so many new monsters and a fun endgame loop. i have about 500 hours logged on the ps4 version, so i can definitely say i ' ve had my money ' s worth in game - time! monster hunter world : iceborne is such a great expansion, possibly rivaling mhgen to mhgu. they fixed the horrible lackluster weapon designs, added a bunch of challenging monsters to fight, and made you want to grind for the armor because it just looks so cool!

this is an excellent expansion with a lot of content. i highly recommend it if you liked the original game, as this expansion adds to it in every way. lots of new monsters, new weapon moves, new weapons and armor, new areas, new master rank, and more. i have not experienced any technical problems so far.

from what i ' ve played so far, i love the expansion. problem is the tech issues. i went from smooth framerates and decent cpu usage to nearly half the frames and high cpu usage with lots of heat coming out of my computer. for context, i ' ve just beaten glavenus and nargacuga ; i want to play more, but i don ' t want to risk my computer right i ' ve noticed the weasel - words " should lower cpu usage during active gameplay " in the latest patch supposedly to help with performance ; while my usage dropped about 3 % on average and my cpu temperature never went above 73c, i notice the patch notes said nothing about actually removing the checker bloatware causing the cpu and performance issues. i still experience an average 20fps less than i used to, as well as stuttering and freezing of the game for short times, both things i never used to experience before with base mhw. until this is fixed, my review remains negative and i cannot recommend this in its current state.

mhw was great before the iceborne update, now it ' s an unplayable cpu hogging just almost playable after the last update. it got better but i ' m still running at + 90 % cpu usage and i reach the 100 % mark a lot when i ' m starting the game and when i try to get into a quest. also when the mission complete thing shows up. quite laggy during gameplay so you could play but it ' s not enjoyable. i feel like they still need to optimize the game so it runs just as smoothly as it did pre - iceborne edit 2 : after spending $ 400 to upgrade my pc and capcom releasing a 2nd patch to fix the problems the game now works fine on my rig. : )
it ' s good. cpu issues are being fixed but they weren ' t that bad for me anyway.

mhw was great before the iceborne update, now it ' s an unplayable cpu hogging just almost playable after the last update. it got better but i ' m still running at + 90 % cpu usage and i reach the 100 % mark a lot when i ' m starting the game and when i try to get into a quest. also when the mission complete thing shows up. quite laggy during gameplay so you could play but it ' s not enjoyable. i feel like they still need to optimize the game so it runs just as smoothly as it did pre - iceborne edit 2 : after spending $ 400 to upgrade my pc and capcom releasing a 2nd patch to fix the problems the game now works fine on my rig. : )

capcom released an update that first of all fixed the save data issues, that is a good thing definitely but i spend 40€ on a game that i currently can ' t play because of the still high cpu usage. is it really necessary to have two anti cheat programms that actually get my cpu to 100 % usage even after the patch? the cpu usage of this dlc is ridiculous. i really like monster hunter as a series and iceborne ( for the consoles ) is well done but holy moly did they fcked this pc port up.

fortunately i am able to use the dx12 api which improves my performance significantly. however, even with that i still get 100 % cpu usage at the hoarfrost reach and the ancient forest, co - op seems to also increase the cpu usage as no i will not change my fps cap from 60 to 30, this is pc version not console though i love all the new monster and features added in this expansion. most of the pc fan base is unable to access it as they may have different graphic card that wont support dx12 and most of the time will have max cpu usage 100 % just to play in a playable know what to do capcom, remove of the most effective solution to reduce the cpu usage is literally by using a cheat software to bypass denuvo abusive scanning procedure. it is too ironic how this expansion pushes the fan base to use a cheat software to play the game love mh, been playing this series for a long time and its sad how one of its best expansion is being undermined by a fatal way of counter measuring cheaters which just punish the players that wants to play know you want us to get the best monster hunting experience. cheaters do destroy the immersion of players that wanted to hunt fairly, but denu

expansion works great and runs smoothly in 100 + fps with most settings maxed ( high end pc ). nothing but good things to say about it. so much content and so much new stuff that it really is an expansion not a dlc. i heard about saves getting deleted so just copy your save or wait few day / weeks till they put out a patch. overall 1080 ryzen x3700 16gb ram

this review is from someone who had none of the technical issues reported by other people. this isn ' t to say those issues don ' t exist or aren ' t severe, just take that into is mhw perfected. every weapon has been given new moves and depth, with everyone having access to the slinger while their weapon is drawn. flash pods feel less impactful and higher - risk play is encouraged in master rank, with old monsters also learning some new tricks. ( tzitzi ya - ku is a great example with how he now adjusts his stun the big tool of this expansion is the " clutch claw " - essentially you grapple a monster for a number of options while taking on the risk of an unavoidable clutch claw, as huge as it is, isn ' t the only awesome new tool. all of your mantles can be upgraded and can also hold decorations now, allowing for some more flexible builds. every palico tool has a new function available through leveling them up as well, ranging from placing decoys to one - time res. the options are varied and all pretty cool to play with. music is fantastic. we ' ve got some more great tracks coming too with rajang, and the sound quality

he drools completely destroy the flow of a would recommend the extension to anyone who liked the original monster hunter world, but i was really disgusted by the clutch claw mecanic and i wish that you will like it instead of me.

it can feel like a chore / alienate potential bad : - if you were hoping for decoration grind improvements, be disappointed. there ' s more of them now to further clog the claw ( though an interesting mechanic ) is clunky and flawed in its implementation. the damage and knockdown it gives you is incredible, and it does require skill to use effectively, but it ' s implementation and over - reliance on mantles can make it frustrating to use both for new and returnee players. only being able to claw in cardinal directions to knock down monsters makes it harder to use and more dependent on monster position, all the while forcing you to wait for a good opportunity to use it should your mantles be on cooldown. it ' s tough, and i still flub it here and there. - tenderizing is again, a super powerful mechanic that ' s great in theory and super poor in implementation. in essence you whack the monster a bit after clutch clawing to it, and the specific part you tenderize will take increased damage and increase your crit - rate when you hit that part. it once again, is really reliant on mantles to consistently use, and this is primarily due to the different speeds at which different

over kulve tarroth in many ways and the highly customizable weapons are great. there ' s also less rng with getting the weapon you want. there is, however, 10x more rng in customizing the weapons, unless you minmax them with only stat increases, then it ' s fast and simple. unfortunately, the weapons start with poor stats so the bulk of upgrades need to be put into stat increases just to be competitive options. utility upgrades, while great, are overshadowed by stat increases, and wanting to do anything interesting means making a weapon sub - par. want an extra decoration slot? great idea, except that you can get several decorations worth of attack, affinity, or sharpness in that slot making it a waste. set bonuses are a little more enticing, but have the lions share of rng, and are still a net loss in dps with few exceptions that really only work for professional speedrunners. bowguns seem like they were designed with greater customization in mind, especially looking at their deviation, but then had their upgrades nerfed without any re - adjustment. they still manage to add a few interesting options, but it also seems like the devs are terrified of giving them anything nice

options : 1. move to a different part ( bad idea ) 2. force move the monster direction ( only done from the head ) and 3. tenderize or launch monster forward ( only from head ). now that i ’ ve explained the basics of this mechanic, here is why the claw ruins the game for me : you are forced to use it multiple times a hunt in order to cause enough damage to complete the hunt in any meaningful time. there were cases where i was using a lance, which is generally a lower dps weapon by itself, and i would constantly fail hunts at the 50 minute mark. this doesn ’ t feel good to break the pace of the fight by needing to stop every 3 minutes to tenderize a part of the monster so you do more damage to them. this isn ’ t even taking into consideration monsters like rajang, nargacuga or barioth that act like they just snorted a line of cocaine if you so much glance in their direction. this means you need to carefully aim the claw at the head to launch or a part to tenderize with just a couple of second window before you ’ re smacked off at best and wombo - combo ’ d into a cart at worst. oh, and you must do this every

no. you can indeed use the claw to fire your slinger ammo into the monsters eyelids to cause it to turbo forward into a wall or something, knocking it down for some free slappage. you a, have to get to the monsters head, which with later game monsters takes a lot of good timing to not get thrown off, a bit of luck and it doesn ' t work if they ' re enraged. people are complaining that the weakening system is better for heavier weapons over lighter due to the amount of times you have to claw to the monster and attack a specific spot to ' weaken ' it and give you extra damage. logically that makes sense, to get the damage of 1 hit of a hammer, you have to do multiple with dual blades for negative review stated that the monsters do little attacks that " punish you for trying to do this thing you didn ' t actually want to do in the first place ". yeah, you have to time your claw grabs to avoid these things. use rocksteady or temporal to weather the flinch attacks that knock you off. cc to the monster when it ' s exhausted and not moving. another is that it ' s finicky and you don ' t always grab the place you ' want ' it to.

bad idea as the slinger shot will virtually always rage the monster, and the stun from the wall bang varies between monsters and ranks. in mr some monsters can be down for as little as 3 - 4 seconds, including the time you ' re falling and sliding across the ground. you might not get off more than 1 swing at the cost of raging the monster that is almost always raged anyway. also, if its raged, the shot won ' t work. if its about to rage, the shot won ' t work. if its - thinking - about being raged, the shot won ' t work. if its one of the god forsaken flying monsters, you might as well buy a lottery ticket to determine if the slinger shot will do anything at all ( this is assuming you can hit the button before being tossed off by the impact of the monster slightly twitching its clutch claw is a gimmick that was given waaaay too high a priority in the expansion, once the newness wears off it becomes a chore that you ' re supposed to be doing constantly. it the subject of monsters, it is, as with every monster hunter game, a mixed bag. whether you enjoy a particular fight is almost always dependant on your equipment and weapon

not long after, a few days later, i went to the fridge. saw our jug in there. what ' s in it? a syrup! what syrup? smell it. oh yes, this is peach syrup again! lift the jug and drink * sluurrp * and drink some more * sluurrp * and drink some more * sluuuuurrrp * aaahh, drink the lot! tl ; dr - best fucking dlc ever made! 10 / 10

on demand as long as the monster is not raging. it is nice to stun monsters, but when you play with the hunting horn ( my main ), hammer, or even the great sword, the gratification you feel from stunning the old - fashioned way ( bonk on the head ) slowly diminishes. those stuns become almost meaningless ( especially when you stun them without the part you are targeting being softened, so you have to choose between doing non optimal damage or wasting the stun with a clutch claw attack, hoping that you ' ll have another opportunity to unleash everything you yeah, i still think the clutch claw is nice, especially the combos it brings with some weapons, but the obligation to soften monsters parts is a distraction that was really unnecessary.
